section_id: ## 3. Calculus of Variations on Path Space

hints.label: def-action-functional-constrained
hints.title: Action Functional with Constraints
hints.content:
861: :label: def-action-functional-constrained
862: 
863: Consider the variational problem:
864: 
865: $$
866: \delta S[\gamma] = 0
867: $$
868: 
869: where:
870: 
871: $$
872: S[\gamma] = \int_0^T L(x_t, v_t, \dot{x}_t, \dot{v}_t) dt
873: $$
874: 
875: subject to:
876: 
877: 1. **Kinematic constraint**: $\dot{x}_t = v_t$ for all $t$
878: 2. **Boundary conditions**: $\gamma(0) = (x_0, v_0)$ and (optionally) $\gamma(T) = (x_T, v_T)$
879: 3. **Viability constraint**: $x_t \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ for all $t$ (path remains in valid domain)
880: 
881: **Lagrangian:**
882: 
883: For the Onsager-Machlup action ({prf:ref}`def-reduced-om-action`):
884: 
885: $$
886: L(x, v, \dot{v}) = \frac{1}{4\gamma T} \|\dot{v} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma v\|^2
887: $$

hints.label: def-gateaux-derivative
hints.title: Gâteaux Derivative
hints.content:
895: :label: def-gateaux-derivative
896: 
897: The **Gâteaux derivative** of the action $S: \mathcal{P} \to \mathbb{R}$ at $\gamma$ in the direction $h \in H$ (Cameron-Martin space) is:
898: 
899: $$
900: DS[\gamma] \cdot h := \lim_{\epsilon \to 0} \frac{S[\gamma + \epsilon h] - S[\gamma]}{\epsilon}
901: $$

892: ### 3.2. Gâteaux Derivative and First Variation
893: 
894: :::{prf:definition} Gâteaux Derivative
895: :label: def-gateaux-derivative
896: 
897: The **Gâteaux derivative** of the action $S: \mathcal{P} \to \mathbb{R}$ at $\gamma$ in the direction $h \in H$ (Cameron-Martin space) is:
898: 
899: $$
900: DS[\gamma] \cdot h := \lim_{\epsilon \to 0} \frac{S[\gamma + \epsilon h] - S[\gamma]}{\epsilon}
901: $$

hints.label: thm-first-variation-om-action
hints.title: First Variation of Onsager-Machlup Action
hints.content:
907: :label: thm-first-variation-om-action
908: 
909: Let $S[\gamma] = \int_0^T L(x, v, \dot{v}) dt$ with $L$ from {prf:ref}`def-reduced-om-action` and the **kinematic constraint** $\dot{x} = v$.
910: 
911: **Method:** We use a Lagrange multiplier $p(t) \in \mathbb{R}^d$ to enforce the constraint, defining the augmented Lagrangian:
912: 
913: $$
914: \mathcal{L}(x, v, \dot{x}, \dot{v}, p) = L(x, v, \dot{v}) + \langle p, \dot{x} - v \rangle
915: $$
916: 
917: The action with constraint becomes:
918: 
919: $$
920: S[\gamma, p] = \int_0^T \left[ L(x, v, \dot{v}) + \langle p, \dot{x} - v \rangle \right] dt
921: $$
922: 
923: **First variation:** For perturbations $h = (h_x, h_v)$ with $h(0) = h(T) = 0$ and $\delta p$:
924: 
925: $$
926: DS \cdot (h, \delta p) = \int_0^T \left[ \frac{\partial L}{\partial x} h_x + \frac{\partial L}{\partial v} h_v + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}} \dot{h}_v + \langle \delta p, \dot{x} - v \rangle + \langle p, \dot{h}_x - h_v \rangle \right] dt
927: $$
928: 
929: Integrating by parts on the $\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}} \dot{h}_v$ and $\langle p, \dot{h}_x \rangle$ terms:
930: 
931: $$
932: DS = \int_0^T \left[ \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial x} - \dot{p}\right) h_x + \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}} - p\right) h_v + (\dot{x} - v) \delta p \right] dt
933: $$
934: 
935: (boundary terms vanish due to $h(0) = h(T) = 0$).
936: 
937: For $DS = 0$ with arbitrary $h_x, h_v, \delta p$, we obtain the **constrained Euler-Lagrange equations**:
938: 
939: $$
940: \begin{cases}
941: \dot{x} = v & \text{(constraint)} \\
942: \frac{\partial L}{\partial x} = \dot{p} & \text{(EL for } x\text{)} \\
943: \frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}} = p & \text{(EL for } v\text{)}
944: \end{cases}
945: $$
946: 
947: Differentiating the third equation: $\frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}\right) = \dot{p}$, and substituting the second equation gives:
948: 
949: $$
950: \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}\right) = \frac{\partial L}{\partial x}
951: $$

hints.label: thm-euler-lagrange-fragile-gas
hints.title: Euler-Lagrange Equations for Fragile Gas Paths
hints.content:
959: :label: thm-euler-lagrange-fragile-gas
960: 
961: Extremal paths of the Onsager-Machlup action {prf:ref}`def-reduced-om-action` satisfy:
962: 
963: **Position equation:**
964: 
965: $$
966: \dot{x}_t = v_t
967: $$
968: 
969: **Velocity equation:**
970: 
971: $$
972: \frac{d}{dt}\left(\dot{v}_t + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) + \gamma v_t\right) = -\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) \cdot v_t + \gamma \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)
973: $$
974: 
975: **Interpretation:**
976: 
977: These are the **deterministic Langevin equations** (the SDE with noise set to zero):
978: 
979: $$
980: \begin{cases}
981: \dot{x}_t = v_t \\
982: \dot{v}_t = -\nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) - \gamma v_t
983: \end{cases}
984: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-134
hints.content:
989: :::{prf:proof}
990: 
991: We use the Lagrange multiplier method from {prf:ref}`thm-first-variation-om-action` to handle the kinematic constraint $\dot{x} = v$.
992: 
993: **Step 1: Compute partial derivatives of the Lagrangian.**
994: 
995: From $L = \frac{1}{4\gamma T} \|\dot{v} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma v\|^2$, define $w := \dot{v} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma v$. Then $L = \frac{1}{4\gamma T} \|w\|^2$.
996: 
997: $$
998: \frac{\partial L}{\partial x} = \frac{1}{2\gamma T} w \cdot \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x)
999: $$
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: \frac{\partial L}{\partial v} = \frac{1}{2\gamma T} w \cdot \gamma = \frac{\gamma}{2\gamma T} w
1003: $$
1004: 
1005: $$
1006: \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}} = \frac{1}{2\gamma T} w
1007: $$
1008: 
1009: **Step 2: Apply the Euler-Lagrange equations from {prf:ref}`thm-first-variation-om-action`.**
1010: 
1011: The combined equation with the Lagrange multiplier $p(t)$ is:
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}\right) = \frac{\partial L}{\partial x}
1015: $$
1016: 
1017: From the $v$ equation in {prf:ref}`thm-first-variation-om-action`:
1018: 
1019: $$
1020: p = \frac{\partial L}{\partial v} - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}
1021: $$
1022: 
1023: Compute $\frac{\partial L}{\partial v}$:
1024: 
1025: $$
1026: \frac{\partial L}{\partial v} = \frac{\gamma}{2\gamma T} w = \frac{1}{2T} w
1027: $$
1028: 
1029: Compute $\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}$:
1030: 
1031: $$
1032: \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2\gamma T} w\right) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T} \frac{dw}{dt} = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}(\ddot{v} + \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot \dot{x} + \gamma \dot{v})
1033: $$
1034: 
1035: where we used $\frac{d}{dt}\nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) = \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot \dot{x}$.
1036: 
1037: Thus:
1038: 
1039: $$
1040: p = \frac{1}{2T} w - \frac{1}{2\gamma T}(\ddot{v} + \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot \dot{x} + \gamma \dot{v})
1041: $$
1042: 
1043: From the $x$ equation: $\dot{p} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial x}$. Compute:
1044: 
1045: $$
1046: \dot{p} = \frac{1}{2T} \dot{w} - \frac{1}{2\gamma T}(\dddot{v} + \nabla^3 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot (\dot{x}, \dot{x}) + \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot \ddot{x} + \gamma \ddot{v})
1047: $$
1048: 
1049: **Step 3: Simplify by using the kinematic constraint.**
1050: 
1051: Using $\dot{x} = v$ and recognizing that for an extremal path, $w = 0$ (the path minimizes the action when the drift deviation vanishes), we have:
1052: 
1053: $$
1054: \dot{v} = -\nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) - \gamma v
1055: $$
1056: 
1057: Differentiating this:
1058: 
1059: $$
1060: \ddot{v} = -\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x) \cdot \dot{x} - \gamma \dot{v} = -\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot v - \gamma \dot{v}
1061: $$
1062: 
1063: Substituting $\dot{v} = -\nabla U_{\text{eff}} - \gamma v$:
1064: 
1065: $$
1066: \ddot{v} = -\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot v - \gamma(-\nabla U_{\text{eff}} - \gamma v) = -\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \cdot v + \gamma \nabla U_{\text{eff}} + \gamma^2 v
1067: $$
1068: 
1069: **Step 4: Verify this satisfies the Euler-Lagrange equation.**
1070: 
1071: For an extremal path with $w = 0$:
1072: 
1073: $$
1074: \dot{v} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma v = 0
1075: $$
1076: 
1077: This is precisely the **deterministic Langevin equation**, confirming that deterministic trajectories are critical points of the action.
1078: 
1079: The fact that these critical points are actually minima (for convex $U_{\text{eff}}$) follows from the positive-definiteness of the path space metric ({prf:ref}`thm-riemannian-metric-convex`). ∎
1080:

hints.label: thm-natural-boundary-conditions
hints.title: Natural Boundary Conditions
hints.content:
1092: :label: thm-natural-boundary-conditions
1093: 
1094: For the action functional $S[\gamma]$ with **free endpoint** at $t = T$, the extremal path must satisfy:
1095: 
1096: $$
1097: \left.\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{v}}\right|_{t=T} = 0
1098: $$
1099: 
1100: This gives:
1101: 
1102: $$
1103: \dot{v}_T + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_T) + \gamma v_T = 0
1104: $$
1105: 
1106: **Physical Interpretation:**
1107: 
1108: At the free endpoint, the path "decelerates smoothly" to equilibrium with the potential, rather than abruptly stopping.
1109: 
1110: **Transversality Condition:**

hints.label: def-second-variation
hints.title: Second Variation (Hessian of Action)
hints.content:
1118: :label: def-second-variation
1119: 
1120: The **second variation** (Hessian) of the action at an extremal path $\gamma$ is the bilinear form:
1121: 
1122: $$
1123: D^2 S[\gamma](h_1, h_2) := \frac{\partial^2}{\partial \epsilon_1 \partial \epsilon_2} S[\gamma + \epsilon_1 h_1 + \epsilon_2 h_2] \Big|_{\epsilon_1 = \epsilon_2 = 0}
1124: $$
1125: 
1126: For the Onsager-Machlup action:
1127: 
1128: $$
1129: D^2 S[\gamma](h, h) = \int_0^T \left[ h_v^T \nabla_v^2 L \, h_v + 2 h_v^T \nabla_v \nabla_x L \, h_x + h_x^T \nabla_x^2 L \, h_x \right] dt
1130: $$
1131: 
1132: **Positive Definiteness:**

hints.raw_directive:
1115: ### 3.5. Second Variation and Stability
1116: 
1117: :::{prf:definition} Second Variation (Hessian of Action)
1118: :label: def-second-variation
1119: 
1120: The **second variation** (Hessian) of the action at an extremal path $\gamma$ is the bilinear form:
1121: 
1122: $$
1123: D^2 S[\gamma](h_1, h_2) := \frac{\partial^2}{\partial \epsilon_1 \partial \epsilon_2} S[\gamma + \epsilon_1 h_1 + \epsilon_2 h_2] \Big|_{\epsilon_1 = \epsilon_2 = 0}
1124: $$
1125: 
1126: For the Onsager-Machlup action:
1127: 
1128: $$
1129: D^2 S[\gamma](h, h) = \int_0^T \left[ h_v^T \nabla_v^2 L \, h_v + 2 h_v^T \nabla_v \nabla_x L \, h_x + h_x^T \nabla_x^2 L \, h_x \right] dt
1130: $$
1131:

hints.title: Stability Criterion via Second Variation
hints.content:
1138: :label: thm-stability-second-variation
1139: 
1140: An extremal path $\gamma$ is **stable** (locally minimizes action) if and only if:
1141: 
1142: $$
1143: D^2 S[\gamma](h, h) \geq \kappa \|h\|_H^2
1144: $$
1145: 
1146: for some $\kappa > 0$ and all $h \in H$.
1147: 
1148: **Jacobi Equation:**
1149: 
1150: The boundary of stability is determined by the **Jacobi equation**:
1151: 
1152: $$
1153: \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial \dot{v}^2} \dot{h}_v\right) - \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial v^2} h_v - \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x \partial v} h_x = 0
1154: $$
1155: 
1156: Solutions $h \neq 0$ satisfying $h(0) = h(t^*) = 0$ for some $t^* \in (0, T]$ are **Jacobi fields**. The first such time $t^*$ is the **conjugate point**.
1157:
